Title: Anonymous
Comment:
While some companies are pure "air charter brokerages," there are thousands of companies operating in "gray areas." Many "travel agents," "VIP concierge providers," hotel concierge services and similar third party planners, even ground transportation providers, "broker" charter flights regularly. What constitutes an “air charter broker”? How would regulations account for current air charter brokers to simply change their name to “travel agent.”  Some small charter brokerages broker only a single flight per week, or even per month, while large “travel agencies” may broker charter flights significantly more. Attempts to regulate “air charter brokers” would have unintended consequences as inevitably companies may find ways to creatively exclude themselves from regulations while still conducting the same services, putting regulated charter brokerages at disadvantage. Further, air charter brokers have, in the past, not complied with existing regulation - I don’t understand how increasing regulations will help solve the problem of air charter brokers that don’t comply. Let’s focus on getting everyone to comply with existing regulation first! In addition, foreign entities broker charter flights in the US everyday and go completely under the radar, putting US brokers at disadvantage. How would an operator know that the person they are selling the charter to was not associated with the passenger group and how will you regulate this?

If the government has approved a part 135 carrier to operate charter service, the burden of “vetting” or safety is on the government and the operator and no one else. While third party charter ratings are good indicators of charter operators’ commitment to safety, they should have nothing to do with regulation. These are completely optional programs that are designed to enhance safety and help spread use of best management practices and communicate to customers, including brokers, that they are committed to safety. If there is going to be any improvements in industry safety, they must be focused on enhancing regulations and programs for the Part 135 operator, not the person that hires the part 135 operator. To say otherwise is to discredit the part 135 certificate holder and government regulations surrounding the granting of a part 135. If regulating the air charter brokers screening process for subcontracted operators, what would be required beyond obtaining the part 135 certificate and perhaps an optional copy of the insurance policy?

Proposals that the air charter broker should be in a “binding contract” prior to presenting the proposed contract to their client is absurd. A binding contract for most oneway flights is non-refundable.

Market forces should regulate air charter brokers. While the Internet has, in the past, increased opportunity for unscrupulous air charter brokers to deceive clients -- similar to every other industry that was effected by a transition to internet marketing -- the Internet of the future will put checks and balances in place that will make clear to a consumer if the brokerage is reputable via online reviews and social reinforcement. Further, market forces should guide all pricing and nothing but taxes should be required to be disclosed to the end client. If the end client wants line item pricing, they can search around for a charter operator or broker willing to provide that. Attempts to regulate pricing are nonsensical in a free market as the broker’s ability to increase margin by negotiating or leveraging discounted pricing should be afforded to the broker and not required to demonstrate to their client of a higher than expected margin.

Air charter brokers should be strictly required to disclose they are a broker and not an air carrier. Deceptive marketing that gives the impression a brokerage is an air carrier should be strictly enforced. Even under current regulations no government official has ever contacted my to discuss this… efforts to better educate brokers would be more beneficial. If a client requests information about the operator they will be on or to be added as an additionally insured on the insurance policy, regulations could help promote disclosure after the contract has been signed and the client is in a cancellation policy window, because there are many clients that would regularly utilize a broker to source a carrier and deceptively cancel with the broker and go direct to the carrier-air charter brokers should not be required to put themselves in a losing scenario. Regulation should be focused on the part 135 certificate and certificated carrier. NBAA and ARGUS among others regularly publish educational material to aid consumers in making good decisions and any savvy consumer only need Google a few keywords to find these resources online.

Title: Paul R. Prescott
Comment:
DOT-OST-2011-0044
Equating the vapor exhaled by an e-cigarette smoker to that of a regular cigarette is completely wrong. Regular cigarette smoke contain nicotine and many other chemicals and by-products, and has indeed proven harmful (althought the harm of second hand smoke has not been proven and has been called into question). e-cigarette "smoke" is water vapor, with very minimal amounts of nicotine if any at all.

e-cigarettes have in a recent study been shown to have no effect on cardiac microcirculation in the smoker, and therefore second-hand vapor is also very, very safe. All well-designed studies to date have proven the benefits and lack of harm from well made e-cigarettes. Those articles that express harm are either poorly designed studies or are pure nonsense (recent French "60 Millions de consommateurs").

As a Pediatrician I discourage cigarette smoking but, if asked about e-cigerettes, I tell people that they, as far as any legitimate studies are concerned, have been shown to be much safer.

E-cigarettes should NOT be banned on commercial flights, especially long distance flights. I have had fellow passengers tell me that they drink more BECAUSE they can not smoke.

If other passengers are paranoid about e-cigarettes then it should be explained to them that they are NOT inhaling second hand cigarette smoke and that the DOT has found the e-cigarettes to be safe and to allow their use.

Sincerely,
Paul R Prescott, MD, FAAP

Title: Karen MacLennan
Comment:
As an Audiologist and advocate for individuals with hearing loss, I believe The Department should require all U.S. airports to provide access to messages and pages broadcast from the PA system in a manner that is accessible to individuals with varying degrees of hearing loss.  It is imperative that all individuals with hearing loss have equal access to auditory information.  Due to the complicated nature of hearing loss, which affects the quantity of hearing (i.e. degree of hearing loss) and/or quality of hearing (i.e. clarity), one system is not suitable to meet the needs of all individuals considered under this proposal.  A dual system with visual display and an induction (hearing) loop is the most appropriate solution.  The induction (hearing) loop system would allow individuals who utilize hearing devices such as hearing instruments and cochlear implants to gain access to auditory information wirelessly via a T coil program and a visual system would provide access to individuals whose hearing loss results in poor speech recognition ability.  An example of a successful induction (hearing) loop can be seen in the Grand Rapids, Michigan International Airport.

Furthermore, it is imperative that access to all messages, essential (alerts, emergencies) and basic information (flight delays, gate assignments etc.) be made available in a manner that is suitable for varying degrees of hearing loss.  Not providing access to all auditory information is inappropriate and inconsistent with the definition of accessibility.  Additionally, it would be prudent to require these proposed changes of U.S. and foreign carriers for consistency for all travelers here and abroad. 

Thank you for the opportunity to post a comment on this important matter.

Title: Carol Madeline Granaldi
Organization Name: Hearing Loss Assc. of America, New Jersey St.Assoc.
Comment: I am a 74 yr. old retired person who over a lifetime lost all of her hearing, and uses 2 cochlear implant hearing devices. I rely to a great degree on use of induction loop/TCoil pairing whenever the loop is available in places like ticket offices, train stations, places of worship and theaters. The loop/TCoil pairing is essential to others like myself who need this assistive enablement to hear more clearly in the above named places because speech is more clear when extraneous surrounding noise is eliminated, and the speaker is using the microphone of the induction loop equipment. I respectfully request that there be such devices installed in airport ticket counters, information desks, and coupled with the announcements at the boarding gates. The induction loops and TCoils are essential to our ease of communication when hearing aids and cochlear implant devices are able to receive the transmission from the induction loop. These devices are more prevalent in Europe, and increasingly are being provided here in the US, such as National Parks, subway systems, etc. Thank you for your favorable support of my comments. Carol Granaldi

Title: Son H. Hoagland
Comment: I am hard of hearing and when I visit an airport or any public building they usually have televisions on.  In some cases the TV's have audio and in some cases they do not.  It seems like it would be helpful to all concerned it all TV's in public places were required to have their closed caption or subtitles on.     There is also a problem if you are waiting for a plane, train or bus to depart and announcements are made, but if you have a hearing problem you are simply in the dark.  You don't know if you number or name has been called or you are to board or what.  Seems to me it would be helpful if a person, when checking in, could advise the attendant that they were hard of hearing and needed help in boarding.  They should be able to sit in the disabled section and given some boarding assistance??????  Very difficult for a person that has a hearing problem to travel.

Title: David G. Myers
Comment:
The hearing loops in Grand Rapids Airport are wonderful!  Visual information gives me the basic departing time, but announcements (such as regarding boarding timing or flight delays) give so much more information.  How wonderful to have them wirelessly broadcast by my own hearing aids!  

The nearby Kalamazoo and South Bend Airports also now are accessible to people with hearing loss through hearing loops . . . and the U.S. Department of Transportation anticipates putting out for public comment a mandate that future passenger rail and subway cars have hearing aid compatible assistive listening (which means, for the present, hearing loops).  

How wonderful it would be if all U.S. airports were made auditorily accessible.  

News Release 


February 3, 2012 
Contact: Bruce Schedlbauer, Marketing and Communications Manager 
(616) 233-6053
bschedlbauer@grr.org


Ford Airport Expands Hearing Loop System

Gerald R. Ford International Airport officials have announced the expansion of the hearing loop system installation at the airport. This system enables individuals with telecoil (T-coil)-equipped hearing devices to have public address system announcements transmitted directly to their hearing aids. This assistive listening service is available on both airport concourses, at all airline gates and holdroom areas, and now in the airport’s Grand Hall.

“We are delighted to offer this service to our customers who use assistive hearing devices,” said acting executive director Phil Johnson. “By the direct transmission of gate and flight announcements to T-coil-equipped hearing aids, this hearing loop system significantly enhances the airport experience for the thousands of our customers who have experienced hearing loss. And now, this service is available in more areas of the passenger terminal building.”

Additional information about hearing loop systems is available at www.hearingloop.org.

Title: Rhea Harper
Comment: Because of my hearing loss airline travel is most difficult.  Lucky for me I do not travel alone; otherwise, I could not hear any of the announcements within the airport nor in the airplane.  Traveling makes me feel helpless and anxious.

Title: Bruce J. Harris
Organization Name: Hearing Loss Association East Bay chapter
Comment:
Inductive hearing loops should be installed in an area near each gate. I have a moderate hearing loss, and can never understand the announcements and must continually ask a hearing person what was said. Traveling is a stressful experience as I am always nervous about missing my flight.
Loops don't require much maintenance and don't require travelers to have any equipment except their hearing aids, they are an ideal solution for assisting my disability group.

Title: Elizabeth Lansing Hupp
Comment: I lost my hearing as an adult and by age 50 had received two cochlear implants.  I hear quite well--in some situations.  I travel by air several times a year and have great difficulty understanding speech in airports.  I want to voice my support for induction loops at ticket counters and departure gates, as well as visual announcements.  Using my telecoil setting with an induction loop greatly enhances my ability to comprehend what is said over a public address system or what is said to me in a noisy ticket area.  In some airports I have seen announcements (such as delays and gate changes) scrolling at the bottom of screens in gate areas.  This is also tremendously helpful and makes air travel much less nerve-wracking for me.  Many times I depend on the kindness of strangers to comprehend what announcements are being made--not exactly an ideal solution.  I appreciate the availability of induction loops to use with my hearing instruments, and visual announcements as well.

Title: Lawrence J. Brick
Comment:
Disability: Deaf (profound, sensori-neural hearing loss.
For equal access at airports (and while flying)
• video or captioned announcements
     - now boarding
     - change of gate number for boarding

Title: Julia C. Rosenblatt
Comment:
I returned this afternoon from a long plane trip, and was continually frustrated by not being able to hear the airport announcements.  When my flight was delayed one hour, I could see someones lips moving in front of a microphone, but I could hear nothing.  

A visual display with the pertinent information would have kept me informed.  Better yet, a hearing (induction, T-coil) loop would have made it possible for me to hear the announcement.

Title: Lee R. Argabright
Comment:
I am an adult with severe hearing loss and was recently introduced to the benefits of HEARING LOOP TECHNOLOGY.  With my hearing loss, it is virtually impossible to hear announcements over a PA system in large noisy venues such as airports.  If I am traveling alone, I must depend entirely on written information available on various media.  The HEARING LOOP technology is amazing -- it eliminates all local noise interference and gives me 100% understandability.  

It would be a great blessing to have airports, theaters, and other public venues looped to enable hearing disabled persons such as myself to have meaningful understanding of essential messages.

I urge appropriate authorities to provide access to all messages, essential (alerts, emergencies) and basic information (flight delays, gate assignments etc.) be made available in a manner that is suitable for varying degrees of hearing loss.  Not providing access to all auditory information is inappropriate and inconsistent with the definition of accessibility.  Additionally, it would be prudent to require these proposed changes of U.S. and foreign carriers for consistency for all travelers here and abroad. 

Thank you for the opportunity to post a comment on this important matter. 

LRA

Title: Karen L. Bowen
Comment:
Having often been in public places, especially airports, where announcements are made and are totally undecipherable, I think it would be really wonderful to be able to click into my hearing loop and actually hear these announcements.  I once almost missed a flight because of this.  Hearing assistance technology has come so far, and it is time for us to move with it!  Thank you.

Karen Bowen

Title: Linda S. Remensnyder
Comment:
I am a Doctor of Audiology with 40 years of professional experience who has a slight hearing loss and wears 2 state-of-the-art hearing aids. 
My hearing aids have telecoils so I can link into the sound system at venues that have a hearing loop installed due to poor acoustics sacrificing audibility.  Such venues include three U.S. airports as well as those in Great Britain.  Despite my slight hearing loss and my top-of-the-line hearing aids, I cannot decipher the annoucements at airports when the airports are not looped.  I am representing myself and all those patients who have been under my care for 40 years requesting that you provide hearing loops at airports.  It is pertinent that hearing loss is the most common birth condition, 16% of children have hearing loss, 1 in 5 teenagers have hearing loss, hearing loss is the third most common condition in those over 65, and 3/4 of those over 75 have hearing loss.  Encouraging access for those with hearing loss via hearing loops will have more impact than providing access for those with physical or visual challenges.  Also, keep in mind that babyboomers such as myself consitute the population segment that has the most disposable income and are most inclined to travel by air.  In addition, hearing loss is on an upswing because conditions that we are living with (cardiac disease, diabetes, and kidney problems) in conjunction with treatment plans that extend life expectancy (including chemotherapy, loop diuretics, and aminoglycoside antibiotics) CAUSE hearing loss.  Please know that the provision of hearing loops in airports will accommodate a burgeoning population.  We need access for those with hearing loss and you are positioned to make a difference on swelling numbers of our population.

Title: Roberta Brecher
Comment: I am severally hearing impaired and I can no longer travel alone via air due to the fact that I am unable to understand any of the announcements that are being made either before or after boarding a flight.  The last flight I took without an assistant was very frightening.  I found out that we could not land at my airport due to weather, and we were circling for a long period of time until I managed to gather the information from a stewardess.  The airline personnel are much too busy to take time to assist people that are hearing impaired.  Closed captioning or induction hearing would benefit millions of people.

Title: Juliette Philomena Maria Sterkens
Comment: I write, not only as an audiologist with 30 years of experience having helped thousands of people live with hearing loss, but also as a daughter of two parents with hearing loss (my father a Dutch Army veteran who used hearing aids, and my mother who currently uses hearing aids) as well as a niece of a hard of hearing aunt who once missed a flight connection to Oshkosh because she did not hear the gate change announcement, as well as myself, as I now too at age 55 am starting to lose my high pitch hearing,  to give sound QUALITY of audible announcements as well as HEARING ACCESSIBILITY the consideration it deserves at our nation’s airports. According to NIDCD, approximately 17 percent of American adults report some degree of hearing loss and incidence rises sharply with age. Due to the aging baby boomers the total number of individuals living with hearing loss is expected to increase. In over 90% of the time the hearing loss that is experienced is sensorineural which affects not only audibility but intelligibility or understanding speech.  Due to this type of hearing loss, notoriously airport poor acoustics and fast speaking airline personnel, for these millions of people with hearing loss who use hearing aids and 250,000 cochlear implants, deciphering the announcements at our nation airports and airport gates is nearly impossible.  The provision of induction hearing loop technology would greatly enhance the ability of hearing device users to directly hear the announcements wirelessly in their hearing instruments which greatly enhances their understanding and speech discrimination. Hearing loop technology is a worldwide universal technology that, installed to the international installation IEC standard, will not only provide hearing access for the hard of hearing US citizenry but will also be used by millions of visitors – such as my Dutch mother – who have to navigate our increasingly busy airports while trying to understand announcements in a foreign language.

Title: Luis Ben Curet
Comment: Since I developed partial hearing loss one of my most difficult times has been at airports. I have missed flights and have suffered a good deal of anxiety as a result of not understanding announcements made via the loudspeakers. It is a great difference when I am in a looped place like church or theater where I can hear, understand and enjoy the spoken word. Several friends who also suffer from partial hearing loss jhave also told me that they have had similar experiences. We all think that looping airports as well as other public places like train and bus terminals (as well as several others) would improve the quality of our lives tremendously. We certainly back the proposed rule.

Title: Richard Craig Diedrichsen
Comment: Auditory Induction Loops should be required in airports or other places of public transportation acess. They do not require that someone be issued of bring an axiliary device for use since they can be used with a person's hearing aids of cochlear implants. This reduces concerns at secrity stations and prevents loss or damage of assistive listening device recievers.

Title: Hermine Willey
Comment: There are 36 million people in the USA with hearing loss. Many are our Armed Forces returning from Iraq and Afghanistan with hearing loss. One out of three seniors has hearing loss including those with physical disabilities. I am requesting induction loops in all airports for those who have problems hearing in an noisy environment and the sudden changes in flight gates and times of departure and arrivals. I can remember a person who was meeting me at JFK airport sent an announcement over the Public Address System. I never heard this announcement due to all the background noise. Induction loops also serve when an emergency occurs and the people at the airport need to listen to important instructions from TSA. We people who cannot hear will not hear these important instructions for our safety. Inductions loops are devices that send the messages directly into our hearing aids without having to hear background noise. Thank you for listening.

Title: Shirley M. Nauman
Comment: I am a person with severe hearing loss who wears a hearing aid & has a cochlear implant.  While I can hear the announcements at the airport, I cannot understand the words because of poor word discrimination - despite my aids.   I have to ask other passengers what is being announced when I am traveling alone.  It would help enormously to have the announcements CAPTIONED! - or at least to have a hearing loop in waiting areas.

Title: Maxine Belle Barton-Bauman
Submitter Representative: Member Board of Trustees, HLAA Ca.
Comment:
As one of the 36 million Americans with hearing loss, I believe The Department should require all U. S. airports to provide access to messages and pages broadcast from the PA system in a manner that is accessible to individuals with varying degrees of hearing loss.  It is imperative that all individuals with hearing loss have equal access to auditory information.
Due to the complicated nature of hearing loss, which affects the quantity of hearing (i.e. degrees of hearing loss) and/or quality of hearing (i.e. clarity, one system is not suitable to meet the needs of all individuals considered under this proposal.  A dual system with visual display and an induction 
(hearing) loop is the most appropriate solution.  The induction (hearing) loop system would allow individuals who utilize hearing devices such as hearing instruments and cochlear implants to gain access to auditory information wirelessly via a T coil program and a visual system would provide access to individuals whose hearing loss results in poor speech recognition ability.  An example of a successful induction (hearing) loop can bee seen in the Grand Rapids Michigan International Airport.  Furthermore, it is imperative that access to all messages, essential (alerts, emergencies) and basic information (flight delays, gate assignments, etc.) be made available in a manner that is suitable for varying degress of hearing loss.  Not providing access to all auditory information is inappropriate and inconsistent with the definition of accessibility.  Additionally, it would be prudent to require these proposed changes of U.S. and foreign carriers for consistency for all travelers here and abroad.  
Most of the U.K. and other European Countries are looped.
In the next 20 years there will be 70 million individuals in this
country with hearing loss.
Thank you for the opportunity to post a comment on this important matter.

Title: Stepheh O. Frazier
Comment:
I am hard of hearing and, due to excessive background noise I find it impossible to hear and understand emergency announcements, gate change announcements, boarding calls etc. at airports.  This has caused me to either arrive at a changed gate at the last minute or even to miss a flight. There is often no visual system in place to relay the info either.  

This situation could be addressed for the majority of hearing aid wearers like myself if airports and airlines were required to install hearing loops such as those in the Grand Rapids, MI airport to include very prominent and suitable signage that would display the international symbol for hearing access alerting us to the presence of such loops.  This would allow us to turn off the mics in our hearing aids that are amplifying all of the noise while turning on the telecoils to hear only the voice broadcasting the announcement..

There should also be visual presentation of this information at each gate and the entrances to each concourse via a scroll on a visually accessible screen placed above head height and, again, with the international blue ear symbol for hearing access prominently displayed.

Title: Todd Douglas Billin
Comment:
When discussing accessibility in Airports, one topic that is typically overlooked is hearing accessibility.  This is a huge problem in Airports and all types of transportation facilities.  I am a person with relatively good hearing. I recently had a layover in major airport. While walking from one concourse to another to catch my connection, I focussed on the overhead paging system alerting me of all types of general messages and airline information.  The problem is that after almost a 1/2 an hour of walking, I never understood a single message!  I can only imagine how difficult this could be for one of the 36 million Americans (and rapidly growing) with hearing loss.  An even greater concern, these paging systems are the primary source for Emergeny Notification! 

As a communications contractor for over 35 years, I have been involved in the installation of paging systems in many airports and transportation facilities.  Not until we installed Hearing Loop technology in our local airport did I find a solution to Hearing Loss and communications in transportaion facilities (Airports).  Since then we have looped two additional Airports and are having conversations with several more.  This technology works, and it is growing throughout the US.  The A.D.A recognizes 3 forms of hearing assistance in public facilities (somehow airports get an exemption) Infrared systems, Radio frequency system, and Inductive loop system.  Of these 3, the Inductive loop is the only workable solution for Airports, as it is the only system that connects directly to a travelers personal hearing device (Hearing aid) nothing else is required.

  Based on my experiance in Airport communications systems and the installation of inductive loops, the combination of loop systems and visual messaging displays provides the best solution for communicating to ind\ivuals who suffer with loss of hearing and/or visual impairments.  Travelers with Hearing loss is growing as the general population ages.

Title: Randy A. Kirsh
Comment: It is imperative that induction loops be provided for HOH people at airports at ticket counters and at boarding gates, at baggage claim areas and at any other location where it is important that an HOH person be able to hear what is being said by airport or airline officials.  An induction loop is probably the best way for an HOH person to hear what is being said as the sound is fed directly into the hearing instrument w/o intereference from background noise.  The only other way to provide better communication for an HOH person would be by captioning.  A loop can accommodate a number of people as does captioning, but a loop is much less expensive to operate, can be in place all the time, and the induction loop itself is not a great expense.  Loops can be used in small areas as well as large areas.  While captioning is great, the field of vision to see the screen whatever type it might be is limited and is of no benefit to someone who is blind.  A loop can accommodate the blind who are HOH much better than captioning.  Please do not summarily dismiss the idea of using induction loops at airports as they can be a most valuable assistive system to provide access to people who are HOH.

Title: Audio Architects Inc.
Comment:
My business and mission in life is to design and build sound systems and acoustical treatment for public venues (churches, school, courtrooms, theaters, stadiums.. almost any environment) that deliver predictably good speech intelligibility..  Since day one (almost 40 years ago) it was obvious that not all clients could understand speech from even the most expertly designed sound system in an extremely reverberant or excessively noisy environment. People with more advanced hearing loss needed a separate system.  I have installed every kind of assistive listening system on the market (IR, FM, inductive loop and visual displays).

This January I attended a three day work shop on speech intelligibility sponsored by Syn-Aud-Con and taught by preeminent experts in the field.  

Because I misread AM and PM on my plane ticket I had the dubious pleasure of listening to PA announcements in the Gate C area of the DFW airport for over twelve hours as well as on the AA flight home.

The vast majority of announcements (all routine) were barely intelligible  for a non-hearing impaired person in all areas and for a variety of different reasons.  A hearing impaired (anyone with a hearing aid) had no chance of understanding any announcement made anywhere or anytime in the course of that day.  Ironically DFW is one of the more involved airports and actually send representatives to the workshop.

I had many hours to contemplate both the problem and possible solutions.  There really are just two solutions and I believe they both must be employed.  Not doing so puts this and every airport in clear violation of the ADA and risks the safety of thousands of people.

Airlines and airports must deploy inductive loop systems and visual displays in all gate areas at a minimum.  Ideally they would cover much more. 

The attached picture was taken to share as sort of a joke about what AA considered due diligence for speech intelligibility in an emergency situation. It really is not a joke.

Title: Walt Ziemke
Organization Name: Disabled American Veterans, American Legion, Veteran of Foreign Wars,
Comment: As an Advocate of Hearing Loops, as I just had one installed in our home, which I find a God Send, and certainly do support having ANY Public place having a Hearing Loop installed..Being an U.S. Air Force Veteran of virtually two wars, the end of WW II and then served during the Korean War. which who is to say did not contribute to my hearing loss. wearing ear phones most of the time, during flights and working in the Control Towers, in fact, my, hearing aide was/is provided to me by the Veterans Administration due to my encounters, My one ear is not functioning due to a Brain Tumor I suffered, so I am very limited with the ONE hearing aide.  In an Air Port Concourse it is IMPOSSIBLE for me to hear the various announcements.  This is why having Air Ports LOOPED is the ONLY Answer...Thank you, Walt Ziemke, Sr.Citizen. Age, 84.

Title: Sandi Wasserman Enfield
Comment:
I am hearing impaired and I will NOT be able to hear which flight is being called on the loud speaker.

I need to travel by airplanes to get to either child of mine.  I find it extremely hard, or almost impossible.

Can you help me?

Title: Donna J. Penman
Comment:
All airports need CART, Looping and rest stations for Service Animals. I am a late deafened adult and I have a hearing dog.

Title: A. Wayne Benson
Comment: Please consider a rule calling for audio-loops in airports, so that those with hearing loss can access announcements, etc with their telecoil equipped hearing aids.  It is terribly frustrating to not hear announcements to say nothing of the pain of missed flights, wrong gates, etc.!

Title: Julia M. Olson
Comment: I travel alone on occasion and am always on high alert when traveling because I have a severe hearing loss. This is obviously stressful.  In the past, I missed a flight because the gate was changed and I did not hear the announcement explaining that. It delayed my return home overnight.  All airports should be equipped with hearing loops and other communication access technologies, such as text that allow deaf & hard of hearing people to hear or read announcements.  Too often, this population's accessibility needs are ignored. More than 36 million Americans live with the invisible disability of hearing loss. Invisibility is no reason to ignore their special needs.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: The availability of an induction loop in U.S. airports would be a tremendous benefit to the many deaf and hard of hearing individuals like myself that use hearing aids or cochlear implants with a telecoil.  I have missed flights due to missing announcements over the PA system at major airports when the  visual display system malfunctioned.  Please follow the lead of European nations in in increasing the availability of this vital resource in the U.S.

Title: Mike W. Gilbert
Comment:
Some NY subway lines have booths that are captioned. What a difference it made to me in hearing the person in the booth!

Title: Marilyn M. Weinhouse
Organization Name: Hearing Loss Association of America - San Diego Chapter
Comment: Traveling is very stressful for anyone, but especially for people with hearing loss.  As a person with hearing loss and president of the San Diego Chapter of the Hearing Loss Association, I have heard many horror stories of people missing their flights because they didn't hear gate change announcements.  People with hearing loss deserve equal access to any information being communicated over the PA system in an airport. In this day and age, announcements could involve much more than gate changes - essential information related to the passengers' safety.  I urge you to require inductive hearing loops in all airports for the comfort and safety of hard-of-hearing passengers.

Title: Carly J. Girard
Comment: As a Doctor of Audiology, I see the impact of hearing loss on my patient's daily lives.  An announcement made over the PA system in an airport is one example of an ordinary sound that is so easily missed by persons with hearing loss.  It is imperative that assistive devices be available for people with hearing loss to allow them to continue to travel and travel independently.  The best way to achieve this is through a multifaceted approach including a well marked induction loop system and visual messaging.  This is the only way to ensure that people with hearing loss are able to receive the message that their gate changed or that their flight has been delayed.  Creating accessibility for this population is so vital because no one knows who around them has hearing loss and who needs these accommodations.  If someone with a wheelchair needed a door opened, someone would see that and assist them.  If a blind person needed assistance navigating their environment someone would be able to help them.  No one can SEE that someone has hearing loss--we need to be proactive and provide the accessibility that is necessary for them.

Title: Hearing Loss Association of America, Manhattan Chapter
Organization Name: Hearing Loss Association of America, Manhattan Chapter
Comment:
Please consider adding induction loop technology to airports so that airline passengers who have hearing loss can turn a switch on their hearing devices and hear announcements clearly without background noise.  Induction loops will allow a seamless connection directly to the person's ear, eliminating hygiene issues when using other technologies that require the need for an employee to give out assistive listening devices, store them and clean them. Title: Stephen Lewis proces
Comment:
I am hearing impaired and wear hearing aids, as is my mother and my sister. We all travel via airplanes. Hearing the very important announcements made over airport public address systems is almost impossible for most of us with hearing problems. If airports were equipped with hearing loops, we could switch our hearing aids to the Telecoil setting and we would be able to hear everything perfectly. Please set a date that airports of a certain size must install hearing loops so that we can understand announcements.

Thanks!

Title: Debbie mohney
Comment:
As a consumer and advocate for individuals with hearing loss, I believe the department should require all U.S. airports to provide access to messages and pages broadcast from the PA system in a manner that is accessible to individuals with varying degrees of hearing loss. As a consumer, I am well aware that I have the right to equal access to information that is available to people with normal hearing. My loss is not identical to anyone else’s hearing loss, and for that reason, there is no one system that will provide the needs of all people with hearing loss. There is a need to have both a visual display, and a listening system for those people who use hearing devices such as hearing aids and cochlear implants, who have a telecoil program. An appropriate listening system that would not require additional equipment would be an induction (hearing) loop. One airport that currently successfully uses an induction (hearing) loop is the Grand Rapids, Michigan International Airport.
Furthermore, it is imperative that access to all messages, essential (alerts, emergencies) and basic information (flight delays, gate assignments etc.) be made available in a manner that is suitable for varying degrees of hearing loss.  Not providing access to all auditory information is inappropriate and inconsistent with the definition of accessibility.  Additionally, it would be prudent to require these proposed changes of U.S. and foreign carriers for consistency for all travelers here and abroad. 
Thank you for the opportunity to post a comment on this important matter.

Title: Linda Schmeisser
Comment:
I am the mother of an hearing impaired child and also a Hearing Instrument Specialist by profession. I have seen how looping has impacted my daughters' life  and the lives of all our patients in our practice.
Hearing aids have limitations with the microphones. Normal hearing people have trouble hearing the announcements in the airport. The hearing impaired find it impossible. With the loop installed, they would be able to hear the announcements right in their ears, taking out that distance from the speakers to the microphones of their hearing aids.
Please consider looping all airports to make listening accessible to all individuals. It will be life-changing.

Title: Edward J. Szumowski
Comment:
Individuals with a mild-to-moderate or greater degree of hearing loss have a very difficult time trying to hear any messages being broadcast on a public address system, particularly during busy and often noisy periods.  Hearing loops are the mostly widely accessible and universal form of assistive listening system, in that most hearing aid users have the telecoil feature required for access to the loop.

As a practicing audiologist with over 35 years of service to the hearing impaired, I have too often heard the frustration, anxiety, and fear that patients with hearing loss experience in settings like this.  And the solution is pretty simple!  I strongly urge that inductive hearing loops be installed in public areas in airports and other transportation centers.

Title: Elise Wachenfeld de Papp
Comment: Anything that can be done to make airports more accessible to those with hearing loss would be greatly appreciated. Going to the airport is a daunting prospect for those of us who have difficulty conversing. Waiting at the ingate is probably the worst time, not knowing when you're supposed to line up, etc., in the cacophony of sounds coming at you.

Title: Lisa H. Bailey
Submitter Representative: janiceslintz@Gmail.com (please forward response also to her)
Comment:
Please add induction loop to the Rochester Monroe County 
Airport. There is a large deaf  and hard of hearing population 
in Monroe County and this should be given at this point. LONG OVERDUE! We need to know what is going on , kept 
in the loop by an induction loop so to speak.Please forward this response also to 
janiceslintz@gmail.com.
Thanks. Lisa H. Bailey

Title: Elaine C. McCaffrey
Comment: As a hearing impaired individual who has worn bilateral hearing aids for over three decades I greatly appreciate being able to comment about the need of both captioning and an induction loop system to be available in all airports.  In general, at the airport and specifically at the ticket counter I hear the sound of what is being said, but I cannot distinguish the words being spoken by the attendant or over the public address system; if there is visual captioning I am able to learn of flight delays, gate changes, who is being called to board, etc.  An induction loop system allows the speakers voice to come directly from the speaker’s microphone into my hearing aids with no unwanted background noise.  Think of the millions of baby-boomers who are or will be hearing impaired that will benefit from both captioning and the induction loop system in our airports. This will allow independent travel for many hearing impaired individuals.

Title: Reinaldo N. Bonachea
Comment:
I am hearing impaired and travel a few times a year. When someone at a gate makes an announvcement I know enough to ask someone nearby to repeat (the agent has a microphone in front of their mouth) or have to go up to the counter and make a line to ask what the announcement was. When announcements come over the PA system, I am out os luck because I can not be asking people nearby every few minutes to repeat announcemnets that in the majority of cases do not apply to me.
I wear a hearing aid and a cochlear implant. If the airport had an induction loop, my T-Couil would pick it up and I could have equal access to the announcements.

Title: Suzanne O'Connor, Au.D.
Comment:
Installing induction hearing loops in airports is one of the surest ways to comply with the mandatory accessibility standards set forth by the Americans with Disabilities Act for people with hearing loss and to make their airport experiences significantly easier and more enjoyable. Airport induction loops would allow those with hearing loss to receive announcements directly in their hearing aids, bypassing the background noise that can render these critical announcements completely inaudible.Patrons of airports in Michigan as well as international airports, like Heathrow in London, have already experienced the incredible benefits of hearing loops, but airport looping should not stop there. The rising number of people with hearing loss means that more and more people who patronize airports will require ADA mandated accommodations to be able to hear and properly in the airport environments. Now is the ideal time to install induction hearing loops in airports across the country to serve the increasing population of those with hearing loss. 

In our Indianapolis audiology practice, we have installed a hearing loop in our waiting room, and have hosted several consumer education events to advocate for their installation, because we truly believe that they are the best way for those with hearing loss to receive the mandatory equal access they deserve. Many types of venues can benefit from installing hearing loops- from churches to taxicabs. Airports, however, have a special need for hearing loops. When a person has hearing aids, the amount of ambient noise created in airports leads to muddled sounds and missed information. A person should not have to accept sub-par access to information and sound because of a hearing loss in any environment, period. We urge all airports to recognize that those with hearing loss deserve equal access by installing induction hearing loop systems as soon as possible.

Title: Virgil Fenn
Comment:
As an person with hearing loss, I believe The Department should require all U.S. airports to provide access to messages and pages broadcast from the PA system in a manner that is accessible to individuals with varying degrees of hearing loss. It is important that all individuals with hearing loss have equal access to auditory information from the PA system. Due to the complicated nature of hearing loss, which affects the quantity of hearing (i.e. degree of hearing loss) and/or quality of hearing (i.e. clarity), a single system is not suitable to meet the needs of all individuals considered under this proposal. A dual system with visual display and an induction (hearing) loop is the most appropriate solution. The induction (hearing) loop system would allow individuals who utilize hearing devices such as hearing instruments and cochlear implants to gain access to auditory information wirelessly via a telecoil, which is included in most hearing aids. A visual system would provide access to individuals whose hearing loss results in poor speech recognition ability. An example of a successful induction (hearing) loop can be seen in the Grand Rapids, Michigan International Airport.

Furthermore, it is imperative that access to all messages, essential (alerts, emergencies) and basic information (flight delays, gate assignments etc.) be made available in a manner that is suitable for varying degrees of hearing loss. Not providing access to all auditory information is inappropriate and inconsistent with the definition of accessibility. Additionally, it would be prudent to require these proposed changes of U.S. and foreign carriers for consistency for all travelers here and abroad. Thank you for the opportunity to post a comment on this important matter.

Title: Julie Kneip
Comment: When someone has a hearing loss, one of the most common complaints is an inability to understand speech in the presence of background noise. Other issues that compromise an acoustic signal are distance from the sound source, an inability to visualize the speaker's face for visual cues, reverberation of noise in the area, and other distractions--all of which degrade the sound source in airports.The only way to ensure that people with hearing impairment are able to overcome all of these obstacles that prevent them from hearing a gate change, a delayed or cancelled flight, or other pertinent flight information is the installation of a hearing loop in airports. Hearing loops allow a hearing aid user to link directly into the sound system via the telecoil of the hearing aids so that he/she may hear the announcement clearly into his/her hearing aids (clearer than normal hearing individuals who must filter out the background noise). Without the installation of hearing loops in airports, hearing impaired individuals are being denied the access they deserve to  information about their travels.

Comment: As an advocate for the people that are hard of hearing, I'd like to offer comments based on my members' feedback.  The TTY stations are not clearly marked in the airport terminals.  However, TTY is old technology and today, most deaf/hard of hearing (HOH) people use a relay service, mainly video phone. Title: Clark O. Anderson
Comment:
When you are hard of hearing or deaf, understanding speech whether through a sound system or person to person, ranges from difficult to impossible.  The risk for people who are hard of hearing like me or deaf is that you will fail to understand announcements though the standard sound systems (e.g. change of gate, delay of flight, emergency notification etc.) or through face-to-face speech (e.g.,  meal choices, check-in questions or instructions, TSA announcement or instructions).  
At least two factors are involved in this problem for everyone: poor quality sound systems and background noise in airports and airplanes, both of which make it difficult for people with “normal” hearing to understand speech.  These problems are magnified for me and others who are hard of hearing or deaf, not only because my hearing deficit is profound but because even with the current level of sophistication in hearing aids and cochlear implants that amplify filter and focus speech, along with amplification of speech, background noise is also amplified.  The result is that these noises still mask or fully drown-out the speech you need to hear.  
There are two ways that speech information in airports and airplanes can be made to accommodate us.  One is by a loop system, the other is by captions.  For example, loops at ticket counters and gates would increase our understanding of announcements and instructions and at gates providing captions along with loops would go further to increase understanding.  Similarly, having announcements and instructions by TSA personnel who are interacting with passengers fed into a loop system would allow much better understanding on our part and avoid misunderstandings on their part.  Airplane cabins should looped as well so that attendants’ and pilots’ announcements are understood by us.  
These recommendations are not just made to make airline transportation pleasant for us—they are directly related to our safety.

Title: Betty Hill Buckley
Comment: I am hard of hearing and have macular degeneration. My hraring aids have telecoils so it would be a great help to me to have airport information areas looped for hearing. Title: Linda L. Diaz
Organization Name: Hard of Hearing and Deaf Services
Comment:
I have had moderate to severe hearing loss for over twenty years. Even though I wear hearing aids I cannot understand verbal announcements at the airport because of background noise. This fact is extremely stressful to me and causes my travel experience to become challenging. I do use the reader boards. I often travel with a 'normal hearing' person so that I know what is going on. But this limits my ability to be independent. 

I use induction loop technology everyday. I have it connected to my television set. One of the aspects of my business, Hard of Hearing and Deaf Services, is to hook up loop technology for people. I also teach them how to use their T or telecoils in our hearing aids that allows us to pick up the signal sent by the induction loop. For people that don't have T coil enabled hearing aids there are receivers and headsets a person can wear to hear the signal. This is wonderful technology and I would not be able to enjoy music or television without it. It also allows me to be able to hear on a cell phone.

Induction loop technology is 75 years old. More and more people are becoming Hard of Hearing as the Baby Boomers age and there will be greater demand for this technology. It is my understanding that many airports in Europe already have this technology set up. It would be wonderful to have it here in the United States. It would ease our ability to travel and hear important information. It would also help to have emergency information relayed over the loop system. Flashing lights to let us know there is an emergency and to tune into the loop system would allow us to be able to hear instructions that could save our lives.

Title: Lesley Bergquist
Comment:
As a person with hearing loss it is very difficult to communicate in airport situations. It can be confusing, intimidating and even frightening. What happens if I can't hear a security question and don't answer or answer Inappropriately? If there is an alert and someone yells "stop!" and I don't because I didn't hear it, then what?

All of the information that is available to "normal" people is inaccessible to me unless it is in visual form (warning lights), writing (captioned), or transmitted directly to my hearing aids (a loop system).

Another issue is training personnel to understand that hearing loss is not visible and many people do not want tell the world they have this disability. Hearing loss is usually not the first thing that comes to mind when a person appears confused. There are several ways to make interactions easier that could be included in "sensitivity training" programs.

 A growing percentage of the population has hearing loss and it will continue to affect the safety, security and well-being of everyone.

Thank you for taking this invisible and overlooked issue seriously.

Title: Stephen John Woolley
Comment: Airports, almost universally, exhibit a reverberant acoustic environment.  Without exception, research shows that hearing aid users have a poor to useless experience with their hearing aids using their internal microphone(s) in such an environment. Hearing aids can work very well in intimate, acoustically dry - non reverberant spaces, or outdoors in one-to-one situations.  The moment one is immersed in a noisy or reverberant space, the onboard microphones can become worse than no hearing aid at all.  Unless of course, they have T-Coils equipped devices and there is an AFILS- audio frequency induction loop system properly installed and operating to accepted standards.  Suddenly announcements and appropriately mic'd counter staff can be heard and understood. Confusion and discomfort in an already stressful situation are thus considerably reduced and a person needing the assistance and involvement of special and additional personnel is obviated.   In the long term, by filling these needs with an installed loop system, personnel costs for an airport facility are reduced and the intended goal of providing a comfortable and pleasant user experience is achieved. Without good and effective AFILS  - Hearing Loops, we will not reach these goals in our airports!  Europe does a considerably better job than the USA in providing these valuable services.  Since the installation costs and operation over time are less than the continuing personnel costs, let’s do the right thing and support the whole community and not exclude people or create a less than inclusive experience.

Title: Wynne W.
Comment:

Signed. Someone who doesn't meet the label of "hard of hearing", but does wear hearing aids for a moderate loss. I can hear, but usually/often cannot understand what is communicated when traveling throughout airports.

Title: Pauline Amanda Weiss
Comment: I would like to see hearing loops and visual displays installed at airports in the U.S.  As a person with hearing loss, I can never understand what is being said over the speakers at an airport or inside the plane - despite my $6,000 hearing aids.  When I fly by myself, this adds much stress to the trip.  It would be so helpful to know what is going on around me.  Especially when things go wrong.  Like the time there was a security breach at D.I.A.; I had to keep asking someone next to me to tell me what was going on as they could hear what was being broadcast but I couldn't.  A flight delay can be a real nightmare as I try to keep up with what is currently happening.  Even on an uneventful flight, it would be great to know if there is a gate change, or when to board, etc.  If there were a loop system installed, I could simply change my hearing aid setting to t-coil and the sound would be fed directly to my aids, allowing me to hear.  Thank you for your attention to this important matter.

Title: Bruce D. Nelson
Comment:
There are several communications +problems facing deaf and hearing-impaired passengers at airports.

Deaf passengers are unable to hear any boarding, gate change, or other announcements. Hard-of-hearing passengers have problems hearing and/or understanding the announcements due to the background noise, or gate agents who talk too fast on the P.A. system or have accents which make it difficult for HoH passengers to understand.

Therefore there needs to be a multi-faceted approach to helping both populations.

A real-time captioning system with a display at each gate position, and displays around the terminal could be considered. There could be system where all announcements are typed in and voiced by a high-quality text-to-voice system and at the same time displayed on sign-boards, or, there could be a real-time captioning system similar to TV or telephone captioning where captions are transcribed by an operator (to overcome the accent/speed problem) and displayed on sign boards. There should be some type of notification like a strobe light to announce attention to any new message.

In addition, audio-loops could be installed at gate positions to help HoH passengers who don't especially need the captioning, but need to be able to hear the announcements while being able to tune out the general noise in the terminal.

As a HoH individual, I find it extremely difficult to hear general terminal and gate announcements and have had to resort to asking strangers to repeat announcements for me. Deaf/HoH pasengers should be given the same opportunity to receive important information as hearing people.
