Title: Sara Nagel, Au.D.
Comment:
As a Board-certified Audiologist, I can attest to the limited benefit even high-end hearing aids provide hearing-impaired users in reverberant, noisy environments like airports.  Installation of induction loop systems around ticket counters and passenger gate areas is a simple solution that would benefit innumerable hearing aid users passing through U.S. airport terminals.  
Although I have normal hearing, I have listened to speech over  a microphone in a reverberant environment with my ears alone and then through a telecoil-equipped hearing aid.  The improvement in clarity due to the signal-to-noise ratio increase is astounding.  For hearing-impaired persons who typically can tolerate less noise than normal-hearing individuals, the improvement is that much more critical.  
Approximately 70% of hearing aids distributed in the U.S. currently have telecoils within them that allow receipt of crystal-clear induction loop signals with a simple press of a button, while temporarily eliminating background noise, echo, and reverberation.  Once installed, induction loops require minimal to no maintenance, and would provide equal access and immeasurable benefit to hearing impaired travelers passing through U.S. airport terminals.  
Sara Nagel, Au.D.
The Center for Audiology
Houston, TX

Title: M. R. Blumer-Reed
Comment: I believe that it is imperative that hearing induction loops be required in all airport terminals.  Even individuals with normal hearing are often very challenged to hear information at the boarding gate; but for anyone with a hearing loss the ability to hear vital information is impossible.  Requiring hearing induction loops will give access to independent travel to those wearing hearing aids with tele coils - approximately 70% to 80% of those wearing hearing aids.  Not only is the induction loop important to give travelers with hearing loss necessary information regarding their travel, but also to ascertain that possible emergency and/or safety information be disseminated clearly and completely to those of us with hearing loss.  I am a member of the Hearing Loss Association of America (HLAA), Chicago North Shore chapter, an instructor in speech reading, and a facilitator of a weekly hearing loss support group.  Please support hearing induction loops in our airports and make accessibility a reality for more than 30 million individuals who are managing hearing loss in their lives.

Title: Harold Lonny Rosenman
Comment:
Captioning, clear, readable instructions and/or induction loops are required at many points at airport facilities including:
1. check-in/ticketing counters - induction loops would assist with understanding the varied questions and instructions given
2. baggage checks - Pro-forma instruction sheets to assist with the simple procedure and answer frequently asked questions
3. security processing - both written instructions as the passenger approaches the screening point and induction loops to facilitate instructions/questions given/asked while the passenger is being screened
4. departure gate - easily visible captioning to assist with boarding
5. Passport and Customs checks at arrival points - induction loops essential to assist understanding of questions posed.

Title: Margaret C. Snyder
Comment:
I am profoundly deaf, but am blessed with cochlear implants. In my view, without doubt the most efficient and effective service for the deaf is the hearing loop, which, once installed, needs no extra technology from the presenter or the listener. Just connect the loop to the loud speaker and we deaf can tune in by flicking our personal technology, whether hearing aid or implant, to its t-switch (telephone switch). 

Why is it that the Europeans are so very far ahead of us Americans in using this technology? For a deaf person, it is like having someone standing beside you....so easy to hear, and with no interference from airport noises.

Let's move America to the front of the line!

Title: Kim Ward
Comment: On two occasions I have nearly missed my flights because gates were changed and I couldn't hear the announcements.  Normally when a gate change occurs, my local airport posts it on a reader board, but it sometimes happens that the reader board does not get updated in a timely manner.   It would be very helpful if airports had induction loops so that I might be able to hear announcements with my hearing aid and cochlear implant.

Title: Namati Katungu
Comment:
As a person who has auditory acuity, I am always frustrated when I travel by flight because of lack of access to effective communication. Starting from booking,  transit within the airport, boarding, in flight announcements, arrival, to baggage claim, people without auditory hearing acuity have access to effective communication while the communication access needs of those with auditory acuity are ignored. It is estimated that more than 10 percent of population in the United States have some degree of auditory acuity, and their communication access needs are not addressed by the airport services.

I suggest that the FAA should strive to make all airports communication accessible by integrating auditory and visual communication technology with the current communication systems. Hard of hearing people who depend mostly on using their residual hearing by using cochlear implants and hearing aids equipped with telecoil switches will benefit from hearing induction loop system. More than 70 percent of hearing aids and 100 percent of cochlear implants manufactured in the United States are compatible with hearing induction loop system. In Europe such as United Kingdom, most of the major airports have induction loop systems.
For people who are deaf with several to profound hearing acuity will benefit from visual communication technology such as smartphone applications that utilize text format in real-time captioning, and LED Scrolling message boards. Smartphone applications will be more ideal because all people either with or without auditory acuity can login at various applications to obtain information in text format.
Therefore, FAA should require all airports in the United States to address the communication access needs of all people.
Thank you!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Airports are extremely difficult environments to hear clearly in.  The announcements are inaudible even to those with good hearing; for the hearing-challenged, visual display or captioning of information is an absolute requirement for equal access.

Title: Cheri Perazzoli - Comments
Comment:
I am Vice-President of the Washington State Hearing Loss Association; the state’s leading organization representing people with hearing loss. I am also a frequent flier with progressive severe-profound hearing loss and have worn hearing aids since I was 19. 

While raising a family, I traveled alone, cross country, several times a year with my two young daughters. I frequently missed gate change announcements, and had to rely on my daughters to do the listening for me. 

Recently, I traveled to Ireland/England and discovered hearing loops at the airports, the train stations, the tour bus, the pharmacy counters, the museums and the auditoriums!  Simply by pushing a button on my hearing aid, I was able to clearly understand. In my carry-on bag, I normally travel with an arsenal of assistive listening devices; after 3 days in Dublin, I realized they weren’t needed. I could leave them in the suitcase and lighten my load. 

Hearing loss is an invisible disability, that impacts daily communication for me and 1 in every 5 Americans—1 in 3 at age 65. Hearing Loss is a significant public health issue; the World Health Organization warns hearing loss will be the most prevalent disability in the future, yet little is being done to create a hearing accessible world. 

I am advocating for accessibly designed airports. These would have: 
-Universal Hearing Access Signage—apparent as soon as you walk through the doors.
-Barrier free hearing loops and signage at each check-in desk and other points where critical information is exchanged
-Gates & Airport Terminals would be designed with hearing loops so travelers who wear hearing aids or CI’s can understand announcements.
-Hearing loops would be installed to meet the IEC60118-4 standards,

Accessibility makes a trip easier and more enjoyable for people who experience limitations in vision, hearing mobility or memory. 

Please read my full comments in the attached document. 

Sincerely, 
Cheri Perazzoli
Vice President, HLA-WA

Title: Pamela Souza - Comments
Comment: I have been an audiologist for 20 years.  In that time I have worked with hundreds of individuals whose hearing loss isolates them from many activities and services available to individuals with normal hearing.  As someone who travels frequently, I can attest that airport acoustics are dreadful.  Announcements are broadcast that are distorted, in echoing rooms, produced by less-than-clear speakers; and where even normal hearing travelers turn to each other to ask what was said. Hearing-impaired travelers simply cannot hear these - and they represent a significant portion of the US public.  Putting aside for a moment the necessity of hearing when one's flight is leaving, what about safety?  I have been in airports when announcements were made about severe storms or tornadoes and a need to move immediately away from windows; and where there has been a security issue and important and unexpected announcements are made. Travel should NOT be in the category of activities that are restricted because of hearing loss.  At least one simple solution exists: loops in airports.  I urge you to implement these as quickly as possible.

Title: Rachel
Comment: I am in support of all airports having induction loops so that those with hearing aids may better hear. Airports are unfriendly acoustic environments.

Title: Pamela Fiebig
Comment:
As an audiologist I hear many comments from my patients about fear of airline travel  due to inability to hear announcements at airports.  Announcements at airports should be available to people who are hearing challenged.  The use of induction loops in such areas will allow hearing aid and cochlear implant users of any age to easily hear the same announcements their hearing counterparts hear.

Induction loops are cost-effective technology that transmit the sound from the loudspeaker directly to the hearing aid or cochlear implant user’s ear via magnetic signals. Most hearing aids and cochlear implant processors may access the loop with the "flick of a switch" at any time, and the system can accommodate an unlimited number of users simultaneously.  It is a timely, cost-effective means of providing improved communication to thousands of hearing impaired individuals passing through  airports and other public areas.

I recently traveled to the UK and noted that many public areas in airports, train stations, museum, etc   are equipped with this technology that makes sound accessible to those with hearing loss.   The US needs to follow suit.

Title: Vicki O'Reilly
Comment: Loop systems in airports for those with hearing loss is an excellent idea and is long overdue!

Title: Susan M. Lopez
Comment:
As an audiologist who promotes looping, I cannot begin to tell you how powerful having access to hearing loops could be for the over 30 million Americans who report having hearing difficulties.  Hearing loops are powerful because they REALLY DO eliminate background noise and help the signal the person wants to hear (airport announcements) come through clearly via their hearing aids and/or cochlear implants.  

Hearing Loops are a proven technology that is relatively inexpensive that can make a profound difference in the lives of those with hearing loss.  A majority of hearing aids sold in the US are equipped with telecoils and can pick up sounds from a hearing loop.  Sadly, hearing loops are not universally available to the public, and many people do not even know about them or how powerful they are at improving hearing.   Our nation is far behind Europe and other developed countries in providing accessibility and public awareness for hearing loops.  If every airport was looped, people with hearing loss would have much less anxiety about traveling by air, because they wouldn't have to worry any more about missing a flight or a gate change because they couldn't hear the announcement.

Hearing aids alone are not enough in an airport because the acoustics in an airport are notoriously bad.  Airports are large, often with high ceilings, a lot of reverberation, and a lot of sound competing for our attention.  A person using the hearing loop can set their hearing aid so that it ONLY picks up the sound from the loop, thus ensuring that they can clearly hear all the announcements coming through the loop.  PLEASE provide this funding to install hearing loops.  It is a matter of important public health and creating accessibility for all in a public space.

Title: Liz Tusler
Comment: Airlines rely on intercoms and loudspeakers to make announcements. For hearing impaired individuals, this is a major issue. Looping airports would be a dramatic change for the ease of travel for hearing aid users.  People depend on airport loops all over Europe. Why not here?! It's a permanent and cost effective way to assist a large number of people and likely increase travel.

Title: Claude A. Lucchesi
Comment:
The work of looping public places is very important to make hearing-impaired persons able to function almost normally.
I am very pleased that you are carrying out this work.

Claude A, Lucchesi, Ph.D.

Title: William Daniel Zimsen
Comment:
Airports are tough for hearing impaired.  What is needed most is TRAINING of personnel. 
Some years ago, I was in wheel chair at MSP, at the gate waiting for flight.  Gate was changed but I did not get it. Later, The agent, having talked to me before, wheeled me down to the plane.  I made a smart crack about the jetway; if longer we could walk to Dulles.  Just as I was going thru the airplane door, a voice behind me said "Dulles, ?  I am going to Laguardia.  And I am driving. " Turning around I saw the Captain. Almost got an untended trip to Laguardia.
  At the reservation desk, people need training.  Especially those of other cultures who don't like people close to them.  One time I leaned toward a soft spoken Indian girl so I could hear her.  She stepped back.  A couple of those dance steps, and I asked for other help.
  At SFO, I was given pat down because of CI. I wear loose pants because of a pinched nerve in my hip.  Explained to the security guard.  He was not listening.  Told me to remove suspenders, then did rub down of legs.  Pants went to ankle, in front of 120 onlookers.  (It was San Francisco ..  my son says they are used to naked people so it was no big deal.) 
  Training for those who deal with hearing impaired - as well as other kinds of impairment - is clearly lacking. 
PA systems are universally unintelligible. Face to face communication is often vital.  Sensitivity of staff toward hearing impaired is sadly lacking.

Title: Edward O. Belcher
Comment: I support installation of induction loops in airports that allow the hearing impaired to hear the PA system with their hearing assisting devices set on Telecoil.

Title: Sara Elizabeth Kennedy
Comment: As a mom to a deaf teen and a frequent airport traveler with my deaf and hard of hearing colleagues, I support the use of hearing loops and visual displays installed at airports in the U.S. When I travel with adult professionals who are deaf or hard of hearing, they do have to rely on others to learn about announcements and instructions. As a hearing person, I have difficulty hearing the announcements in noisy airports, so all would benefit from visual displays.

Title: Avis
Comment:
At the airport (in USA) I got frustrated when the person announced the messages at the public announcement.  I sat down and had no idea what happened.  Was my flight delayed? Changed to another flight?  I often felt anxious and I looked at the hearing strangers – to see what they did so I followed them.  One time I was almost to miss my plane because I did not know that they changed the gate.  I always let the gate attendants at the gate counter know that I am deaf.  When they announced the message via PA, they never came to me and told me what the message was about.  One time I sat down and I was puzzled that I was only person to sit at my gate.  I went to the counter and wrote the note to ask the gate attendant.  She told me to go to the Gate #.  I was in a hurry to walk far to the other gate and boarded the plane just before the gate attendant closed the door.  Whew! I would have missed the plane and I was mad at the gate attendant for not telling me after she knew I am deaf.  My deaf mother always felt anxious when she went to the airport because the staffs did not help her.  She missed her plane twice because the staffs did not notify her.  Another time she waited and waited for her flight so she went to the gate counter and asked the gate attendant about her flight.  She was told that the plane had a mechanical problem so she had to wait for the other plane to come.  She hated to go to the airports.  The staffs need a training – to HELP the deaf people by communicating with them like they would announce to the hearing travelers. 

I want to require for all airports to install the closed captioning in a visible public announcements at all gates.

Title: Anonymous
Comment: When there are changes to be make at the airports, they generally are not interested in informing me or helping me.  I noticed when people started moving away from the area where their flights would be, to other area which gave me the clue that they are changing the planes and schedules.  Prior the changes, I let them know that I don't hear and need their help when there are any changes and they acknowledged it, but they really aren't interested in helping me.  They don't care whether I might miss the plane or get on wrong plane, so I rely on people's behaviors.  What they need to do, is to put signs in front of their poduims for people to read, or using TV monitor when there are changes.

Title: Krista Parker
Comment: Airports and airplanes in general are not good for hearing impaired. TV's need to be captioned for sure, but the people who work in the airports and on the airplanes, need to be educated on hearing loss and how to handle it. We as hearing impaired people, have "dealt" with it all our lives, we know what we need and we are willing to teach and tell you, but employees need to be open to that teaching. The other thing that would be good, is written word, either on the screen on the plane or have a stewardess write it down, whatever the captain says so we're not left out.

Title: Vickie Pacheco
Comment:
As a hard of hearing person, I need accessibiliy to "hear" EVERYTHING that is going on in the airports - everything that is broadcast on the PA about anything.  Emergencies, evacuations, paging, change of gates - "everything" means everthing -I can't be much plainer that that and it's not any more complicated than that.  

That could be done with "looping" the airports, having captioning on the monitors, captioning boarding info so I know when my section is called (or even the person at the gate holding up a sign for the current section).

I have missed being paged by my parents to know where to meet them, missed boarding calls, have difficulty heariing at the ticket counters, transportation counters - anywhere there is anything spoken.  

I feel like a foreign traveler right in my own country's airports because I can't hear or understand what I'm hearing.  

It's time to address the needs of the deaf and hearing impaired.  There are all kinds of things for the blind and those in wheelchairs.  It's time to address this population that has been overlooked. Please help make airports accessible FOR ALL.

Thank you.  

Vickie Pacheco
Vice President Colorado Springs Chapter
Hearing Loss Association of America

Title: Ann M. Belfiglio
Comment:
I strongly support accommodations for deaf and hard of hearing individuals in airports.  Hearing announcements in airports is often difficult for people with normal hearing, with hearing loss it frequently becomes impossible.  Installation of loop systems would greatly enhance the travel experience for individuals who wear hearing aids equipped with a t-coil.  Visual communication systems would aid deaf clients as well as those who are hard of hearing but do not have hearing aids with t-coils.  They would also be beneficial to normal hearing individuals who cannot always make out overhead announcement as well. 
The normal stress of traveling is compounded when you are fearful that you may miss an announcement about a gate change      or worse yet, an emergency announcement.  Appropriate accommodations could make a great difference to those of us who require them.

Title: Karen Kanter
Comment:
As an American Sign Language Interpreter for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing, I have advocated for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing community for 30 years.  I am now personally dealing with my own hearing loss.  During recent instances of travel, I have experienced difficulty understanding announcements at airports across the country. I believe The Department should require all U.S. airports to provide access to messages and pages broadcast from the PA system in a manner that is accessible to individuals with varying degrees of hearing loss.  It is imperative that all individuals with hearing loss have equal access to auditory information.  Due to the complicated nature of hearing loss, which affects the quantity of hearing (i.e. degree of hearing loss) and/or quality of hearing (i.e. clarity), one system is not suitable to meet the needs of all individuals considered under this proposal.  A dual system with visual display and an induction (hearing) loop is the most appropriate solution.  The induction (hearing) loop system would allow individuals who utilize hearing devices such as hearing instruments and cochlear implants to gain access to auditory information wirelessly via a T coil program and a visual system would provide access to individuals whose hearing loss results in poor speech recognition ability.  An example of a successful induction (hearing) loop can be seen in the Grand Rapids, Michigan International Airport.
 
Furthermore, it is imperative that access to all messages, essential (alerts, emergencies) and basic information (flight delays, gate assignments etc.) be made available in a manner that is suitable for varying degrees of hearing loss.  Not providing access to all auditory information is inappropriate and inconsistent with the definition of accessibility.  Additionally, it would be prudent to require these proposed changes of U.S. and foreign carriers for consistency for all travelers here and abroad. 
 
Thank you for the opportunity comment.

Title: Sheri Gostomelsky
Comment: Even with the best fit of hearing aids, listening in noise poses the greatest challenge. Hearing aids can benefit the ability to hear live spoken speech but when speech is presented through a microphone or loudspeaker, it becomes distorted.  In order to hear clearly, the most economical solution is to listen with  hearing aids through an induction loop which allows for distortion free hearing. This simple system allows an unlimited number of hearing aid wearers to act independently and hear overhead announcements with ease.  Please consider the installation of induction loops in our airport terminals; allowing access for improved communication.

Title: Karen E. Kirkpatrick
Comment: My bilateral cochlear implants help me greatly, yet I feel disabled in airports. Recently, when I couldn't hear and didn't know where to go, I appealed for help at several approachable places such as rent-a-car counters but was told that it was not their job and instead they had to sit idle in case a customer approached. Understandable, yet I really needed help and was in a panic! I will greatly appreciate any improvements you make in airport accessibility.

Title: Janice Schacter Lintz
Comment: I have been told and I do not know if this is accurate, but it is my understanding that the Quantas Lounge at LAX airport has an induction loop.

Title: Sarah Anne Mathews
Comment:
Airports are generally very confusing places for deaf and hard-of-hearing people.  I have had trouble at airports, and I have a severe to profound hearing loss.  I personally would probably not benefit from an audio loop.  However, the airports are definitely not deaf or hard-of-hearing friendly.  Here are some ideas to improve accommodation:
1.  Audioloops
2.  Visual information at the gates to indicate whether the plane is on time and when it is boarding, and any delays and reasons for delays.
3.  Allow deaf and hard-of-hearing people to highlight the lines for their flights by allowing the text to be larger and in a different color and yet easily readable.
4.  Larger signs for restrooms and for wi-fi tables and wi-fi areas.
5.  Encouraging deaf and hard-of-hearing people to board with  elderly people and people of various disabilities.
6.  Assigning escorts for hard-of-hearing and deaf people who need additional information about their flights and luggage to help them navigate around the airport.
7.  Training of airline personnel and airport personnel about people of various disabilities with simple handouts for different kinds of disabilities and have that training once a year - basic training then refresher courses.

Deaf and hard-of-hearing people fly just like blind people and people with mobility handicaps.  Please make the airports more accessible to deaf and hard-of-hearing people.

Title: Deborah L. Carson
Comment: Over 36 million Americans have some degree of hearing loss.  As an audiologist, I see a number of patients who despite using hearing aids, struggle with hearing in noisy situations, such as airports, restaurants, ticket counters etc..   These individuals lead active lifestyles and feel isolated, frustrated, and fatigued when spending hours struggling to hear.   Induction loop technology, commonly  available in public locations across Europe, allows the hearing aid user to utilize his/her own hearing aids  to directly receive the audio signal via a magnetic field.  The use of induction loops at ticket booths, information counters, in transportation systems, on the concourse will transmit announcements from the agent or PA system directly to an individual's hearing aids, without all the background noise.   Informational or emergency messages can be easily heard enhancing communication and safety.  Induction loop technology is an inexpensive way to address the needs of those with hearing loss in public venues and should be avaialable in airports across the US.

Title: Cathy Kooser
Comment: As a person with severe hearing loss who travels frequently it is imperative that accommodations improve in U.S. airports for people with hearing loss.  It is extremely difficult to understand any auditory annoucements made by airport personnel.  As such it's necessary to provide more timely and accurate visual messages.  Captioning of all announcements using voice recognition software would be highly beneficial, as well as providing hearing loop technology for those who wear hearing devices.  Sensitivity training for airport personnel related to hearing loss would also help.  Hearing loss is the 3rd largest disability in the U.S. behind arthritis and hypertension.  More people have hearing loss than have visual problems!  It's time to make the much needed improvements to increase our ability to understand verbal instruction and information throughout all airports in the U.S.

Title: Terry Chayefsky
Comment:
It is necessary for hard fo hearing people like myself to fuction at airports. All announcements, ticket desks and any area where possible instructions are given.
I have had some hair raising experiences where I  almost missed a flight. for example; The gate was changed. i was not aware of this at all. There were others

Title: Vivien Tessa Maisey
Comment:
My nearest airports (JFK and Newark, NJ) have no "pet relief area" inside the terminals beyond security.  Traveling with a service dog , especially on a long flight (USA to UK for instance), means  that my hearing dog will be unable to relieve herself for as much as 10 hours.
I am grateful that airline staff have always accommodated my hearing loss, by escorting me through security and baggage claim, but I am now reliant on a hearing dog and am very concerned about flying with her.  
If the type of facility is consistent at all airports, it would be possible to train one's dog to use this before traveling.  Perfectly housetrained animals cannot be expected to suddenly eliminate inside, which is exactly what they may have been trained not to do.  We need to know what to expect so that we can retrain accordingly.

Currently the nearest international ariport to my home with a relief area inside is in Washington, DC, a 5 hour drive away.  ALL airports should have inside relief areas for service animals.

Title: Jerry Bergman
Comment: As a late-deafened adult with severe hearing loss, I struggle to hear in all but the quietest situations. In airports, and everywhere that PA systems or loudspeakers are used, I am unable to understand what is being said.  I urge the FAA to require both induction loops and visual message board displays in all domestic airports.  The induction loops, such as those installed at the Grand Rapids, MI, Airport, enable the vast majority of us who wear hearing devices to understand announcements by hearing them through our telecoil programs.  The message boards enable the deaf, those who cannot wear hearing aids, and those with hearing loss who cannot afford hearing aids to read the announcements. Installation of loops should be required of all airlines at ticket counters and at all boarding gates.  It is time the U.S. assured hearing access at airports as Northern European countries do.

Title: Ruth Bernstein
Comment:
I'm an 80 year old with a profound hearing loss and find
 air travel extremely stressful because I can't hear announcements  at the airport.  In addition to  written displays of all announcements,  looping that would provide  access to  those of us with t switches  in our hearing aids would help diminish our acute travel anxiety.
Thank you for considering this request.

Title: Martin Finkel
Comment: It is extremely necessary to install hearing assisted devices at airports. I have been an in transit and have been unable to hear the announcements because the airport is not looped. In addition I do not hear the hostess announcements during the flight although I do here  the pilot suggesting the pilot has hearing looping technology.

Title: Al Chen
Comment: I am a frequent traveller and cannot understand any important annoucements being made.  This makes travelling unnecessarily difficult and dangerous at times.  Providing very simple accomodations like hearing loops, captioning and signs would make a very big difference for the 36 million+ hearing impaired individuals to have a safe and enjoyable travel experience like those individuals without any impairment.

Title: Jane Anne Seifert
Comment: Looping the ticket and information booths and putting captioning type displays to write the verbal announcements is essential for those with hearing loss.  Pls make sure these are added to airports.  Thank you.  Jane Seifert

Title: Anonymous
Comment:
I am late deafened and would find air travel alone very stressful. Fortunately I have not traveled alone and would not savor the thought of such an ordeal. Please consider posting gate changes in a quicker fashion along with captioning flight information at the gates as it seems hearing people have difficulty understanding the announcements. 

Thanks for your consideration.

Title: Yvonne Mutzi Brown
Comment:
It is so sad that we are in the 21st century and flying on the airlines is all mumbo-jumbo when they display their safety rules, no CC on the airlines  while everyone else has the pleasure to enjoy a movie on flight and no real way to find out what they serve or buy while flying.
Yet we pay same fare like hearing and get far less.

Title: Ephraim Leibowitz
Comment: AS A US CITIZEN WITH A SERIOUS   HEARING LOSS AND VISION ISSUES, I NEED TO HAVE AIRPORTS LOOPED SO THAT I CAN UNDERSTAND THE INSTRUCTIONS AND MESSAGES BEING MADE AT AIRPORTS..

Title: Karen Sue Smith
Comment: Please do your best to get service dog relief areas located inside the sterile zone. I travel frequently and often have connecting flights with short time intervals between them. We have to wait to be last off the plane with our wheelchairs and then are expected to be first on board for the next flight. With bathrooms on planes not accessible, I have to find time to use the bathroom facilities myself as well as taking care of my service dog's needs. Having to go all the way out to the front of an airport and then have to go through the entire TSA screening again makes this entirely impossible. The screening also takes longer as we have to wait for a female officer and the patdown procedure takes forever. It would probably take a minimum of 2 hours between flights to accomplish this and there is never that much time. At one airport, the only way to let my dog get relief was to have an airport employee take her from me and disappear to "someplace" that they could take the dog. This is entirely unacceptable having to separate me from my service dog, especially to a stranger. The look on my dog's face as she was walked away by a stranger spoke volumes. She looked back at me the entire time until they were out of sight. She could not understand why she was being separated from her responsibility. It was heartbreaking and very stressful. Please don't make us ever have to go through that again.

Title: Romin'Judy Sheppard
Comment:
RE:  SERVICE DOG RELIEF AREAS

This is SO important for service dogs and their humans.  Since we (the team) have to be at the airport as much as 2 hours before a domestic flight, it means we can't relieve our dogs for at least that time plus the length of the flight plus travel time to & from the airports(s).  That means our dogs are having to hold their business for many many hours.  Not only is that uncomfortable for the dogs, it is unhealthy.  As my service dog's human, if I can't let him relieve himself prior to boarding, I worry that he'll have an accident somewhere - embarrassing for both of us - and an inconvenience as well.  My dog has a larger bladder than I do & my first stop after deplaning is the bathroom!!  There is a limit to being able to "hold it."  Regarding the location of these relief areas.  Please make them convenient for the human to get to as well as the dog.  (I.e., not in some remote corner of a parking lot).  If we have to go back through security after using the relief area, that just adds much more time & inconvenience to the trip.  Travelling is difficult enough these days without compounding the burden.  Thank you for your attention to this matter - not exactly national security, but awfully important to both members of service dog teams!!

Title: Anonymous
Comment: Took long time to install baby changing table in public restrooms. Especially mensrooms. It will take some time to install flushable dogy grassy pads toilets in handicap bathrooms at airports,malls, etc.

Title: Tim Earl Hamilton
Comment: I was on an American Airlines flight from Dallas to Seattle a few years back and after we had boarded, the aircraft pulled away from the building, moved to the other side of DFW and sat for 8 hours. The aircrew had to call for a refuel truck to give us enough gas to make it to Seattle. Once we were finally underway the aircrew came over the intercom and told us the reason that they didn't pull back to the building is because they knew the flight attendants would bolt because they were on overtime. The reason they give us for the delay was becasue a thunderstorm was within ten miles of the airport...for eight hours? What I'm not getting is the fines...the DOT isn't the ones sitting on the aircraft for long periods of time and are in just maybe a small way inconvinienced. Why not make the airlines pay the passangers upon arrival to their destinations for their inconvinience...the passengers are the ones that should be compensated. But I would be willing to listen to anyone that would be willing to explain to me why the government gets the money instead.

Title: Keith Fredriksen
Comment:
I am against lifting the 3 hour tarmac rule for airline passengers.  This is for CITIZEN protection.  It doesn't matter the cause of of an airline delay -- DO NOT PUNISH CITIZENS.

How do I communicate this to the right DOT Department??????

Comment:

Title: Cathy McNair
Comment:

Title: Blythe Construction, Inc
Submitter Representative: James P. McBryde Chief Estimator - Vice President
Comment:
September 23, 2013
Document Management Facility
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave. SE, West Building Ground Floor, Room W12-140
Washington, D.C. 20590 - 0001
Re: Disadvantaged Business Enterprise: Program Implementation Modifications
       DOT Docket ID Number OST-2012-0147
Gentlemen:
      Blythe Construction, Inc. is one of the largest highway and bridge builders in the State of North Carolina and we support the DBE Programs established here in North Carolina. It has come to our attention that one proposed modification to the DBE NPRM involves the required submittal of a Good Faith Effort with the Bid.  From a Contractor’s view point and perspective, we would like to present some reasons and facts why we think this would be difficult to achieve. 
1.	Bid submittals for NCDOT Proposal’s are generally due by 2:00 PM the day of the Bid. We receive quotes and evaluate quotes up until bid time; however, we typically have made our selection of subs and suppliers by 12:00 noon. We enter our Bid pricing first and then our DBE commitments. Until those commitments are entered, we are not 100% sure if we have obtained the goal or not. We typically select DBE subs in selected categories based on type of work that historically generate DBE participation. Sometimes the DBE is not chosen based on price, past performance, or other relative criteria. If our initial analysis indicates we are not meeting the goal, we first look at the DBE quote categories not selected. We then determine if it was based on price, how much more will we add to our bid and what percent of impact that has. The DBE could be 40% higher than a non-DBE sub, but the monetary difference is only 0.10% to our total bid. We would probably use the DBE quote at this point to achieve the goal. We call this “buying DBE dollars”. We have to evaluate if paying more for the same work will impact the outcome of our Bid versus our competition. We then look at categories of work we typically self perform for which we received DBE quotes to assess if this is worthy of consideration. One has to be mindful that only the low bidder is required to submit a Good Faith Effort if they fail to achieve the DBE Goal. It takes time to make the proper evaluation.
2.	We have prepared Good Faith Efforts to be submitted with a Bid. It is generally in generic format and only provides a brief explanation as to why some DBE quotes were not utilized. There is just not enough time to adequately prepare certain Good Faith Effort responses in an hour or two. We typically expend 2 to 4 hours preparing a Good Faith Effort, not including the ten copies that have to be made. NCDOT requires a response to all 9 and sometimes 10 points of a Good Faith Effort. Additionally they require an itemized comparison of each class of work for which a 
Subcontractor was utilized. This comparison and a detailed explanation as to why a DBE quote was not utilized takes about 2 to 3 hours to prepare. We do not enter into the Bidding process with the mindset that we will not achieve the Project DBE Goal.
3.	North Carolina and many other States use the services of Bid Express and their software (Expedite) for electronic Bid submittals and DBE Committal Sheets. Any Good Faith Effort submittal data would have to be attached to the EBS. Bid File. I am not sure this can be done; however, if possible, it would require a great deal of effort. Copies of quotes for evaluation and comparison purposes probably cannot be attached. Any addition to this existing electronic bidding software would be cumbersome at best. 
   Blythe typically meets or exceeds the Contract DBE goal. Sometimes the goals set are too lofty and cannot be met. DOT is not inclined to defend the basis for the percentage goal set, but they do require us to defend why we did not achieve their goal. Sometimes the anticipated participation of DBE Firms does not happen or due to various reasons they do not quote the total scope of work available. To require a Contractor to submit a Good Faith Effort with their Bid will probably result in Contractors requiring all quotes to be received by 4:00 PM the day prior to the Bid date. Any quote received beyond that time and date will not be considered. Many DBE Firms do their quote preparation the night before or the morning of the Bid date. Requiring a Good Faith Effort with the Bid will place an undue burden on both the DBE Firms and the Prime Contractor. It may result in a Prime Contractor using all DBE quotes possible to achieve the Goal, regardless of price or past experience. Then default the sub at a later date after Contract award. Allowing 6 days for submittal of a Good Faith Effort has worked well for the past 20 years. There is no sound or valid reason to change the current procedure that is in place. 
Sincerely,
Blythe Construction, Inc.


James P. McBryde
Chief Estimator – Vice President

Title: Randy Brand
Comment:
We would like to respond as follows to the listening session point #3 "What are the specific, quantifiable costs and benefits associated with requiring good faith efforts documentation when bids are due and requiring additional documents (i.e., DBE and non-DBE quotes, DBE subcontracts) from the perspective of a prime contractor."

We are a general contractor who has been in business for about 35 years, and perform about $35 million per year of DOT highway work for the Alaska DOT/PF.  We have been fully involved in all variations of the DBE program since inception.  The quantifiable costs we foresee to be associated with good faith effort documentation when bids are due are substantial as it is very likely that the chosen subcontractor on bid day may not truly be low.  We see no benefit associated with this change, and in fact, the potential for harm to be greater.

Things can be hectic during the final few hours of bid day.  Some subcontractors will withhold their bids until the last possible moment to minimize the effect of unscrupulous prime bidders shopping their number.  It can be difficult during this frenzy at times to determine who is truly low due to varying scopes of work, specific inclusions and exclusions, and we will then focus on getting the right amount of dollars in the prime bid, and worry about who is really low if we are successful.  We currently mitigate that by requiring bids to be submitted one hour prior to the scheduled opening.  Requiring that prime bidders and potentially  sub-tier bidders disclose this information at the time of bid will require that prime bidders will require a longer window, perhaps up to the day before, to permit enough time to adequately compile the information.  This will add several hundred dollars to each prime bidder's cost of bid preparation.  This could also add hundreds of thousands dollars to a prime contractors bid should the wrong subcontractor be chosen.  This could also add more time for unscrupulous bidders to shop bids as the opportunity to shop is wide open before the bid but narrows considerably after the bid period as everyone's numbers are then known and it is much more difficult for a prime bidder to shop bids without getting found out by the subcontracting community, who then will "blackball" the bid shopper.

We currently have tools in place to mitigate bid shopping for all subcontractors, both DBE as well as non-DBE. Title: Gulisek Construction, LLC
Comment:
I am writing to you on behalf of Gulisek Construction, LLC.   As a contractor involved in transportation construction projects funded by the US Department of Transportation (DOT), my company is gravely concerned about the proposed changes to the DOT`s Disadvantaged Business Enterprise (DBE) Program (Docket No. OST-2012-0147).  We believe that the proposed regulations will create significant administrative burdens to both the contractors and the state DOT agencies which will result in higher compliance costs. 
Our major concern is that these proposed changes do not consider the challenges contractors face when competing in a low-bid procurement system.  Our specific concerns are outlined as follows. 
LISTING DBE’s AND SUMMARY OF SUBCONTRACT WITH BID
The proposed requirement that prime contractors provide with their bids a list of DBEs that will be utilized on the project, including details about price and scope of work, is unreasonable and we believe will actually result in less DBE participation. 
The nature of the low bid process allows the prime contractor sufficient leeway to maintain its flexibility in executing subcontracts and selecting subcontractors (both DBE and non-DBE) for a project. Typically, the subcontractors submit their bids only a few hours before the prime contractor's bid must be submitted to the DOT. These bids are faxed and possibly discussed briefly over the phone and the prime contractor must hurriedly compile its own bid. This period of time is hectic and the tasks to be completed are complex. Thus, the bidding process puts the subcontractor and the prime contractor in a very different position as to the content of the subcontract. The subcontractors have the "luxury" of preparing their bids on their own timetable, subject only to the deadline for submitting their bids to the prime contractors. The primes, on the other hand, are dealing with all of the various construction aspects of the project and with numerous potential subcontractors. They compile their bids within a few hours of the deadline for submission, and specifics are necessarily given less than thorough consideration and are often left for future negotiations.  
Currently, DBE and non-DBE subcontractors negotiate a fair and balanced formal contract in a good faith manner even after the bid. If your proposed standards are implemented, DBE contractors would be absolved of the ability to negotiate based on the low bidder’s confidential construction methods that may have won the job.  These methods may include a creative plan that the prime contractor will use to build the project at a lower cost. These methods are not disclosed with the subcontractors who are simultaneously communicating with all of the other prime contractors competing for the same project.  Keep in mind that these creative techniques most likely will impact many aspects of the subcontractor’s initial scope.  This ‘locking in’ of the DBE’s at the time of bid will eliminate the mutual acceptance, or “meeting of the minds” component, which is integral to establishing a legal contract.
Furthermore, denying the prime contractors the time to evaluate DBE subcontractors’ quotes post-bid will lead primes to reject all incomplete or potentially inaccurate quotes and to just focus on only meeting the minimum DBE contract goal.  Often times, the time spent on going back to mutually clarify quotes leads to increased DBE participation, which is an opportunity that will be lost if these proposed changes are implemented.  This will inevitably lead to the opposite intent of the DBE program, which is less DBE utilization.  It is for these many reasons that we strongly oppose the listing of DBE’s and the summary of the subcontracts with the bid.  
GOOD FAITH EFFORTS
Equally troubling is the proposed requirement that primes who are unable to meet DBE contract goals must submit their good faith efforts documentation with the bid.  Providing good faith effort documentation at the time of the bid, especially since there is no template or quantitative formula to determine whether a good faith effort has been made, is totally unreasonable. Even the proposed alternative 24 hour deadline for the apparent low bidder to submit its good faith efforts documentation should that contractor fail to reach the DBE contract goal is unreasonable.  We strongly recommend a longer time limit, such as seven (7) days, be allowed for a contractor to provide an accurate good faith effort determination, especially considering the intent to remove the opportunity for prime contractors and DBEs to sit down after the bid to reevaluate the scope, an issue addressed previously. 
It is for these reasons that we urge you to not adopt these rule changes.  Thank you for your consideration of our comments.

We believe that the proposed regulations will create significant administrative burdens to both the contractors and the state DOT agencies which will result in higher compliance costs. 

Our major concern is that these proposed changes do not consider the challenges contractors face when competing in a low-bid procurement system.  Our specific concerns are outlined as follows.  

LISTING DBE’s AND SUMMARY OF SUBCONTRACT WITH BID - The proposed requirement that prime contractors provide with their bids a list of DBEs that will be utilized on the project, including details about price and scope of work, is unreasonable and we believe will actually result in less DBE participation.  

The nature of the low bid process allows the prime contractor sufficient leeway to maintain its flexibility in executing subcontracts and selecting subcontractors (both DBE and non-DBE) for a project. Typically, the subcontractors submit their bids only a few hours before the prime contractor's bid must be submitted to the DOT. These bids are faxed and possibly discussed briefly over the phone and the prime contractor must hurriedly compile its own bid. This period of time is hectic and the tasks to be completed are complex. Thus, the bidding process puts the subcontractor and the prime contractor in a very different position as to the content of the subcontract. The subcontractors have the "luxury" of preparing their bids on their own timetable, subject only to the deadline for submitting their bids to the prime contractors. The primes, on the other hand, are dealing with all of the various construction aspects of the project and with numerous potential subcontractors. They compile their bids within a few hours of the deadline for submission, and specifics are necessarily given less than thorough consideration and are often left for future negotiations.  

Currently, DBE and non-DBE subcontractors negotiate a fair and balanced formal contract in a good faith manner even after the bid. If your proposed standards are implemented, DBE contractors would be absolved of the ability to negotiate based on the low bidder’s confidential construction methods that may have won the job.  These methods may include a creative plan that the prime contractor will use to build the project at a lower cost. These methods are not disclosed with the subcontractors who are simultaneously communicating with all of the other prime contractors competing for the same project.  Keep in mind that these creative techniques most likely will impact many aspects of the subcontractor’s initial scope.  This ‘locking in’ of the DBE’s at the time of bid will eliminate the mutual acceptance, or “meeting of the minds” component, which is integral to establishing a legal contract.

Furthermore, denying the prime contractors the time to evaluate DBE subcontractors’ quotes post-bid will lead primes to reject all incomplete or potentially inaccurate quotes and to just focus on only meeting the minimum DBE contract goal.  Often times, the time spent on going back to mutually clarify quotes leads to increased DBE participation, which is an opportunity that will be lost if these proposed changes are implemented.  This will inevitably lead to the opposite intent of the DBE program, which is less DBE utilization.  It is for these many reasons that we strongly oppose the listing of DBE’s and the summary of the subcontracts with the bid.  

GOOD FAITH EFFORTS - Equally troubling is the proposed requirement that primes who are unable to meet DBE contract goals must submit their good faith efforts documentation with the bid.  Providing good faith effort documentation at the time of the bid, especially since there is no template or quantitative formula to determine whether a good faith effort has been made, is totally unreasonable. Even the proposed alternative 24 hour deadline for the apparent low bidder to submit its good faith efforts documentation should that contractor fail to reach the DBE contract goal is unreasonable.  We strongly recommend a longer time limit, such as seven (7) days, be allowed for a contractor to provide an accurate good faith effort determination, especially considering the intent to remove the opportunity for prime contractors and DBEs to sit down after the bid to reevaluate the scope, an issue addressed previously. 

It is for these reasons that we urge you to not adopt these rule changes.  Thank you for your consideration of our comments.

Comment:
As a small operator with less than 10 motorcoaches we have been severely impacted by the ADA laws. We do not own or operate any wheelchair lift motorcoaches. 

We have many senior clients on fixed income that have worked with us for over 20 years. Our prices for many of these clients has remained well below market as we have found attempts to raise prices result in loss of business to cheaper and less safe competitors or a stop in travel altogether. If one of those clients starts requesting a lift bus and we are forced to farm out the job to a higher cost company (one company has recently quoted a lift bus at $1,000 for a trip we get $700 for). At over $500,000 for a new lift equipped bus which we would have to keep around for a 48 hour demand AND can't use on major sports teams due to decreased seating/luggage space, it puts a company like ours in a no win situation. While our current requests are less than 3 per year, if one of our clients decides they want a lift bus, we are not allowed to let them go to a supplier that can fit their needs.

Further, we have lost significant business during the holiday seasons as Peter Pan was forced to use Lift buses on every run. It seems a far more reasonable approach would be to require the first bus on a run to have a lift with priority seating for those requiring it, and allow the back up bus (the role we played in past years) to operate with out one. 

Thank you.

- Keith Menard, President FTI Coach

Comment:
Commentary Regarding “Procedures for Transportation Workplace Drug and Alcohol Testing Programs” 
FR Doc No: 2013-16789
Filed on behalf of:
Foley Carrier Services, LLC.
140 Huyshope Avenue,
Hartford, CT 06106

Foley Carrier Services provides third-party administrative services to more than 42,000 clients, most of which perform drug and alcohol testing to meet Federal Requirements of the Department of Transportation. Our organization sees tens of thousands of drug and alcohol tests performed every year and our clients come from every state in the union. We have been providing DOT-compliant testing services since 1992.
We strongly encourage the continued collection of information from the Alcohol Testing Form (ATF). It has been our experience that the information gathered on the DOT ATF (as well as the Custody and Control Form) is highly accurate. This data can be used to monitor the overall progress of the DOT drug and alcohol testing program as well as to highlight causes of concern. Studies have repeatedly shown that alcohol is the number one cause of workplace safety issues. We believe that the DOT should continue to administer its program in the successful manner it currently is. This includes the collection and publishing of this vital data.
However, we believe that there are steps that could be taken to improve the collection process. We encourage the DOT to consider moving away from a paper-based system and embrace electronic information collection. We believe shifting to an electronic system would significantly reduce the cost and time burden of the collection. It would also provide more timely access to actionable data. Given the large number of tests performed each year, this would have a positive effect environmentally as well.
Another area for improvement we see is to allow third-party administrators to be a part of the remediation process for alcohol tests as is the case with controlled substances tests. Many motor carriers, particularly small carriers rely on their administrators for guidance and compliance help. Given the DOT’s goal to improve safety on the roads, it is in the public’s best interest that carriers have a means to rapidly share alcohol testing information. Today’s three part form does not provide that capability. In many cases, this leads to a hole in recordkeeping, and, in worst-case scenarios, can result in carriers making the wrong choices regarding drivers with positive test results.
